Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The yearlong thesis project made me a better scientist. I spent one semester building analysis of our simulations, and another semester synthesizing this info, polishing my charts, and tying together everything. I loved every moment. It really depends on who your advisor is but finding one that you jive with well is insanely enriching. I learned how much care, detail and iteration goes into the climate simulations we make, and how much DEBATE sits at every point. It gives me a lot of hope and confidence in the effort of science! At the end of the yearlong thesis our team also made a paper that we hope can be eventually put into a manuscript for review/publication and that's a really satisfying feeling.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: depends on your advisor! make sure you find an advisor and project that you love. And make sure you like the kind of work you're involved with!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I highly recommend the yearlong thesis! you learn so much more and create so much more product than you could in one semester. One semester is only enough time for spin-up and a really minor summary, like a final essay for any other of your STEM courses. But with a year or more of concentrated study, you grow more as a scientist. You'll really create a deep investigation, and learn how much debate and care goes into constructing solid hypotheses and evidences. You also get to invest far more deeply in a lab, which is really really fun!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: this was a senior thesis class so the mode of research depends on your lab! Mine was primarily climate modeling (digital/computational) with in-person advisor meetings, and group lab meetings
